Comment: Philidor's Defense, so called because the great Frenchman never actually played it. Black must play very exactly to avoid being swamped early.

Philidor's Defense, so called because the great Frenchman never actually played it. Black must play very exactly to avoid being swamped early.
A very risky line. Black's normal procedure in this defense is to close the game and play a solid, passive strategy.
Black must do this before recapturing the Pawn [4...PxP? 5 QxQ ch KxQ 6 NxP wins a Pawn.]
The Queen is now bearing on the very weak KB7 square.
Bearing down on KB7, and Black no longer has the option of ... P-Q4 to block the Bishop's diagonal.
Trying desperately to shut off White's attack.
Doubling on the diagonal and also threatening 8 QxNP winning a piece.
Black can choose the location of his death. If 8... K-K2, 9 Q-K6 mate. If, as played, 8... K-Q2 --
-- also Q-K6 mate! Well played by Schmid.
